title: What's the difference between frogs and toads? - Reptiles & Amphibians - Quora

response.answer_text: Toads………………. Live mainly on land as adultsSometimes prey on snakes(but the only species that does is the cane toad) Looks like it is covered in wartsLays eggs in chain-shaped formationWith their short hind legs, they walk like a crawling babyPrefers to crawl this way or use very small hopsBody is stoutFrogs……………….. Have a huge proportion of their time in water as adultsCan’t prey on snakes and mainly prey on insects Smooth skinEggs are laid in clustersCan walk with really large legsPrefers to take big jumpsSlim bodyThose are it!

Technically, asking “what is the difference between frogs and toads?” is like asking “what is the difference between rattlesnakes and snakes?”. Toads are family of frogs, Bufonidae, although there are many species outside of Bufonidae that are called toads. However, I can explain some characteristics of Bufonidae from other frogs. Live in non aquatic habitats as adultsDry, warty skinMost toads crawl because of their short hind legsNo teethMore plump (however, many frogs from different families are even more plump than toads, so this is not a fair comparison)Lay eggs in chain formations Once again, Toads are family Bufonidae, frogs are order Anura which contains toads. So really, toads are frogs and some frogs are toads.
